figures.description: Circular‑flow diagram for Question 2. On the left is a box labelled Households, on the right a box labelled Business Units. A horizontal arrow on the upper side, labelled L, goes from Households to Business Units (real flow of factors); a lower arrow M goes from Business Units to Households (flow of finished goods and services). A circular arrow N completes the flow around the outside. One of the arrows K, L, M, N corresponds to consumption expenditure.

Production table for Question 13. Columns: Number of workers and Total Output (units). Data: (1, 24), (2, 46), (3, 60), (4, 84), (5, 95), (6, 110), (7, 115). Marginal product of worker \(n\) is \(MP_n = Q_n - Q_{n-1}\), and average product is \(AP_n = Q_n / n\).

Short‑run cost and revenue diagram for Question 14. Vertical axis: Price (P), horizontal axis: Quantity (Q). Downward‑sloping demand curve D, upward‑sloping marginal‑cost curve MC, U‑shaped average‑cost curve AC. At price \(P_2\) and quantity \(Q_2\), total revenue is the rectangle \(P_2Q_2\) and profit is the area between price and AC.

Indirect‑tax diagram for Questions 44–45. Vertical axis: price \(P\); horizontal axis: quantity \(Q\). Demand curve D is vertical (zero price elasticity of demand). Two upward‑sloping supply curves: \(S_1\) (before tax) and \(S_2\) (after tax). Initial equilibrium at price \(P_1\) and quantity \(Q_0\); after tax, price rises to \(P_2\) and supply curve shifts to \(S_2\). Areas between \(P_1\) and \(P_2\) along \(Q_0\) represent tax borne by consumers and producers.

instructions.text: In each of questions 1 to 50, choose the option that best answers the question or completes the statement.

questions.question: The ultimate objective of economics is to

options.text: make effort to understand how the economy works
make the best use of scarce resources
organize production at the lowest cost
decide under what circumstances in the economy

questions.explanation: Economics is about **allocating scarce resources** efficiently among competing uses.

questions.question: In the circular flow of income above (figure Econ1995_CircularFlow), the direction of flow of payments for consumption purchases is shown by the arrow
questions.explanation: Households pay money **to business units for goods**, represented by the outer arrow N.

questions.question: A student discovers that he simultaneously needs a biro, an exercise book, an eraser and a ruler, but he can purchase only one of these items. What is the first thing he is expected to do?

options.text: Check how much money he has
Find out which is the cheapest of the items
Draw up a scale of preference
Weigh the opportunity cost of each item against the others

questions.explanation: When faced with many wants and limited means, the first step is to **rank wants in a scale of preference**.

questions.question: What to produce in any society is determined by the

options.text: expenditure of the people on different commodities
supply and demand in the factor markets

questions.explanation: Consumer expenditure patterns (effective demand) signal to producers **which goods are wanted**.

questions.question: The active intervention of the central authorities in the management of a country’s economy rests upon the

options.text: failure of the market forces to produce satisfactorily
superiority of the centrally planned economy over the private enterprise economy
result‑oriented nature of the private enterprise economy
cost‑minimization strategy of a mixed economy

questions.explanation: Government intervenes largely to correct **market failures**.

questions.question: The problems of conducting census include

options.text: high birth rate in the country
poor town planning in urban areas

questions.explanation: Frequent **rural–urban migration** makes it difficult to count people accurately.

questions.question: An ageing population is a population

options.text: in which the number of old persons is increasing
that is dominated by very old people

questions.explanation: An ageing population is one where the **proportion of elderly people is rising**.

questions.question: The population of Ohaha L.G.A. was 480,000 in December 1980 out of which 60% were females. If within one year no births were recorded, but 5% of the males died, what will be the population of the L.G.A. in December 1981?
questions.explanation: Initial males = 40% of 480,000 = 192,000. Deaths = 5% of males = 9,600. New population = 480,000 − 9,600 = **470,400**.

questions.question: What is meant by labour supply?

options.text: number of people in working population
number of men and hours they work
number of hours during which the middle‑aged persons work
number of workforce multiplied by the hours they work

questions.explanation: Economists measure labour supply in **man‑hours**, i.e. number of workers × hours worked.

questions.question: The advantages which firms obtain directly from expanding their operations are referred to as
questions.explanation: Cost advantages enjoyed by a firm due to its own expansion are **internal economies of scale**.

questions.question: The factor of production that has the highest degree of mobility is
questions.explanation: Financial **capital** can usually be moved most easily between uses and locations.

questions.question: Any payment to a factor of production in excess of what is necessary to keep that factor in its present employment is known as
questions.explanation: **Economic rent** is the surplus over transfer earnings required to keep a factor in its current use.

questions.question: Using the production table in figure Econ1995_MP_Table, the marginal product of the 2nd worker and the average product of the 5th worker respectively are
questions.explanation: Marginal product: \(MP_2 = 46 - 24 = 22\). Average product of 5th worker: \(AP_5 = 95 / 5 = 19\).

questions.question: Given that \(TC = TFC + TVC\) and \(TR = AR \times Q\), profit \(\pi\) is equal to
questions.explanation: Profit \(\pi = TR - TC = AR \times Q - TC\).

questions.question: The opportunity cost of the use of productive resources which a producer owns and so does not pay for constitutes
questions.explanation: Forgone earnings on self‑owned resources are **implicit costs**.

questions.question: The effect of changes in the condition of demand on a demand schedule with the price constant is

options.text: hyperbola formation by the demand curve

questions.explanation: Changes in factors **other than price** cause the entire demand curve to shift.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE of the effect of changes in demand and supply on price?

options.text: A decrease in supply will lead to a fall in price and a fall in the quantity bought and sold
An increase in demand will lead to a fall in price and in the quantity bought and sold
A decrease in demand will lead to a rise in price and in the quantity bought and sold
An increase in supply will lead to a fall in price and a rise in the quantity bought and sold

questions.explanation: With demand constant, **increased supply** lowers equilibrium price and raises equilibrium quantity.

questions.question: In a free market economy, available resources are more efficiently allocated by complete reliance on
questions.explanation: In a market economy, the **price mechanism** allocates resources.

questions.question: In order to maximize his profit, a businessman who faces a very elastic demand for his products is advised to

options.text: slightly increase the price of his products
slightly reduce the price of his products

questions.explanation: With **elastic demand**, a small price cut leads to a larger percentage rise in quantity sold and hence higher revenue.

questions.question: What is the price elasticity of demand for commodity X, if at a price of N25 the quantity demanded is 80 and when the price is reduced to N20 the quantity demanded is 100?
questions.explanation: Using arc elasticity: \(E_d = \dfrac{\Delta Q}{\Delta P} \times \dfrac{P_1 + P_2}{Q_1 + Q_2} = \dfrac{20}{-5} \times \dfrac{25+20}{80+100} \approx -1.25\). In absolute value elasticity is **1.25** (elastic).

questions.question: If \(Y\) represents the income earned by workers in a factory, find the range of their income which satisfies the inequality \(4Y - 300 > 500\).
questions.explanation: Solve: \(4Y - 300 > 500 \Rightarrow 4Y > 800 \Rightarrow Y > 200\). (Based on the algebra the correct inequality is **Y > 200**, so the official answer is likely C; however the scanned inequality may have different constants. Please verify with a clearer copy.)

questions.question: Both in the short run and in the long run, a firm maximizes its profits when
questions.explanation: The general profit‑maximization condition is **marginal cost equals marginal revenue (MC = MR)**.

questions.question: In recent times, agriculture in Nigeria tends to lose its vital labour force as a result of

options.text: lack of an effective agricultural policy
employment opportunities in the oil sector

questions.explanation: Many young people leave rural farming areas for city jobs—**rural–urban migration**.

questions.question: Stocking small quantities of a variety of goods is a function of the
questions.explanation: Retailers break bulk and **stock many varieties in small quantities** for consumers.

questions.question: In a joint‑stock company, preference shareholders are those who receive

options.text: high dividends when profits are high and little or nothing when profits are low
a fixed rate of dividend and have the first claim on net profits of the company
the remaining profits after all other shareholders have been paid
dividends quarterly when others receive annually

questions.explanation: Preference shares carry a **fixed dividend** and priority over ordinary shares.

questions.question: The major reason for the survival of small shops despite competition from large business enterprises is because of

options.text: regularity and constant supply of commodities
their local services and longer hours of operation
they take prompt decisions and actions

questions.explanation: Small shops often survive due to **personalized local service and convenient hours**.

questions.question: One of the major advantages of public enterprises is that

options.text: they are the largest employers of labour
they take prompt decisions and actions

questions.explanation: Public enterprises often receive **subsidies**, allowing them to provide services at low prices.

questions.question: When public enterprises become commercialized it means that

options.text: the product of the enterprises are further subsidized
they are expected to operate with the primary aim of making profits
the government has decided to divest itself of such enterprises
the staff of the enterprises will be laid off

questions.explanation: Commercialization requires public enterprises to **operate on commercial, profit‑oriented lines**.

questions.question:
Which of the following statements are TRUE of agriculture in Nigeria? 
I. It provides food for the growing population.
II. A large proportion of the population is engaged in it.
III. Agricultural products are used as raw materials by local industries.
IV. It serves as a source of heavy equipment to local industries.
questions.explanation: Statements I–III are true; IV is false since agriculture does not supply **heavy equipment**.

questions.question: The government can influence the price of agricultural products by

options.text: fixing minimum prices when agricultural output is low
fixing maximum prices in years of bumper harvests
the use of buffer stocks as stabilization funds
paying all farmers producing identical crops a uniform amount of money

questions.explanation: **Buffer‑stock schemes** are used to stabilize agricultural prices over time.

questions.question: The crucial factors which determine the location of petroleum refineries in Nigeria are availability of raw materials and
questions.explanation: Refineries require large amounts of **energy/power**, hence siting near power and crude sources.

questions.question: Infant industries denote industries which

options.text: are too young to compete in the world market
produce baby food and mother‑care products
are allowed time enough to mature for recognition

questions.explanation: An **infant industry** is a newly established industry that needs protection from foreign competition.

questions.question: When compared with a labour‑intensive industry, a capital‑intensive industry employs more
questions.explanation: Capital‑intensive production uses **more machines relative to labour**.

questions.question: The major source of Nigeria’s foreign exchange is the export of
questions.explanation: Nigeria earns most foreign exchange from **crude‑oil exports**.

questions.question: The most important goal of OPEC is to

options.text: present a united front for the purpose of raising prices of crude oil
bring unity among the petroleum exporting states
ensure political stability among member states
ensure that rules on quota production are strictly followed

questions.explanation: OPEC’s primary role is to **coordinate policies to influence oil prices**, mainly by adjusting supply quotas.

questions.question: The Central Bank’s expansionary monetary policy is justified at a period

options.text: when the inflation rate is high and the economy is experiencing a boom
of economic depression accompanied by low capacity utilization
when trade unions are clamouring for higher wages
when the price of crude petroleum is rising

questions.explanation: Expansionary policy is appropriate during **recession or depression** to stimulate demand.

questions.question: The sharp increases in the prices of most goods and services during the last quarter of 1994 in Nigeria were mainly due to

options.text: a ban on importation of foreign goods

questions.explanation: The introduction of **VAT** raised prices of many goods and services.

questions.question: The best method to curb inflation in Nigeria is to

options.text: increase the general level of production
reduce the volume of money supply

questions.explanation: Sustained inflation can be best addressed by **expanding domestic production**, easing supply constraints.

questions.question: A bank is said to be distressed when it

options.text: is unable to deal with the Central Bank

questions.explanation: A distressed bank cannot meet its obligations; it suffers a **liquidity crisis**.

questions.question: One method through which the Central Bank can restrict the commercial banks’ power of credit expansion is to

options.text: buy securities in the open market
reduce the rate of interest at which banks borrow from it

questions.explanation: Increasing **special (or compulsory) deposits / reserve ratio** reduces banks’ ability to extend credit.

questions.question: Which of the following is mostly used to determine the cost of living?

options.text: prices of imported and exported commodities

questions.explanation: The **consumer price index (CPI)** measures changes in the cost of a typical basket of consumer goods and services.

questions.question: The demands made on each other by the agricultural and industrial sectors as the economy grows are reflected in
questions.explanation: Agriculture supplies raw materials to industry (backward linkage) and demands industrial inputs (forward linkage).

questions.question: Foreign exchange rate in a free market economy is determined by
questions.explanation: In a free (floating) system, exchange rates are set by **market demand and supply for currencies**.

questions.question: Using the indirect‑tax diagram in figure Econ1995_Tax_ZeroElastic, the total tax revenue is represented by the area
questions.explanation: Tax revenue equals **tax per unit × quantity**; with perfectly inelastic demand quantity is \(Q_0\) and tax per unit is \(P_2 - P_1\). The rectangle with height \(P_2P_1\) and width \(Q_0O\) (labelled \(P_2EDP_0\) in the diagram) represents total tax.

questions.question: From the same diagram, the tax imposed is borne

options.text: equally by both the consumer and the producer

questions.explanation: With **zero price elasticity of demand**, the full tax can be shifted to consumers via higher prices.

questions.question: Ajanka, a medical student entitled to an annual allowance of N6,000, decides to leave the university to take up a job where he earns N7,000 per annum. By this singular act, the national income level will
questions.explanation: He previously received **transfer income** (allowance) which is not part of national income; by working he now adds N7,000 to NI but loses N6,000 of transfer, so net increase = **N1,000**.

questions.question: An increasing population might be of economic benefit to a country if

options.text: the female population is greater than the male population
the dependency ratio is increasing continuously
a continuously higher proportion falls into the working‑class category
the rural and urban proportions are balanced

questions.explanation: Population growth is beneficial if the growth is mainly in the **working‑age, productive group**.

questions.question: The demands made on each other by the agricultural and industrial sectors as the economy grows are reflected in
questions.explanation: Same rationale as Question 42: **backward and forward linkages** capture such interdependence.

questions.question: Foreign exchange rate in a free market economy is determined by
questions.explanation: Already answered in Q43; **market forces** set the exchange rate.

questions.question: The primary objective of all international economic organizations is to

options.text: ensure that third‑world countries get a better share of the world’s resources
promote international economic co‑operation for the mutual benefit of all members
enforce structural‑adjustment programmes on less developed countries
encourage exports from the developed to the less developed countries

questions.explanation: Organizations like IMF, World Bank and WTO exist primarily to **promote economic co‑operation and stability among nations**.
